page.title: 10TRANSPORT 2 (A595)
page.content: The A595 has been in existence since at least 1700. In the early days this road was travelled by the mail coach, farmers and private carriages. Carrying charges on goods, from Carlisle to Cockermouth, were 2 1/4d per stone and 3/4d per pack weighing over 7lbs. These rates were fixed by the town council. In 1824 the A595 was turnpiked with an average cost of 2d per vehicle, this charge was removed in 1883. The removal of the turnpikes meant that the road had to be maintained by the parishioners of Cockermouth. In the late 1800's the road was made into a main road and the upkeep of it fell on the county.
